webTitle: Co-op Group accused of endangering political party

fields.bodyText: The leadership of the Co-operative Group was accused of conducting an ill-designed attempt to destroy the Labour-affiliated Co-operative party after releasing a questionnaire asking the public whether it should continue to fund political parties. The criticism came after the Co-op Group launched a wide-ranging online survey asking whether it should continue making up to £1m a year in political donations to the party. Peter Hunt, the former general secretary of the Co-op political party, which is allied with Labour and has 32 MPs, including the shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, was sharply critical of the survey and questioned the movement's decision to carry out the poll. Hunt told the Guardian: "The Co-operative party is completely dependent on the Co-op movement subscriptions for its funding. If they were withdrawn, it would mean its abolition, and that in turn would have consequences for the Labour party, and all small political parties, as well as changing the whole culture of politics in Britain." The survey also sees the Co-op Group, the organisation which owns supermarkets, pharmacies, funeral homes and farms, as well as 30% of the Co-op bank, ask the public whether it should pay a dividend to its members when profits allow, and what it can do to help local communities following a series of scandals inside its banking arm. The bank's failed bid to buy 631 branches from Lloyds Banking Group caused a political furore, and was followed by allegations that Paul Flowers, the former chairman of the bank and a member of the main group board, had been involved in buying illegal drugs. Hunt said: "To launch these questions at a time when the Co-operative movement has so many other problems on its hands is strange, especially as there has been no discussion of this issue anywhere else." The Co-op Group took out a series of adverts in many major newspapers on Monday to launch the consultation. Euan Sutherland, who became chief executive last May, said: "In recent years the Co-operative has lost touch with its customers and members and with the communities in which it operates – we haven't been listening." He admitted that full-year 2013 figures, which will be released next month, would be "pretty ugly". The group reported a £599m loss in August, and just before Christmas suspended its dividend to members. There is a widespread view that the Co-op movement is burdened with too large a board, including many directly elected members. This governance structure has led some to argue that it failed to spot the error of appointing the now disgraced Paul Flowers as chairman of the Co-op Bank, who stepped down in the wake of the drug allegations. The results of the online survey will be published with Sutherland's strategic review at the annual meeting in mid-May. The questionnaire asks: "To what extent do you think it is appropriate or inappropriate for big businesses to donate money to political parties?" Other questions concern how the Co-op should distribute profits, its role in the community, and how to improve goods and services. In 2012 the Co-op donated a total of £805,000 to the Co-operative party and its councillors. This included donations to 32 Labour and Co-operative MPs, as well as a one-off £50,000 grant to the office of the shadow cabinet. Sutherland said: "If we get an overwhelming response that says customers don't see the link between funding a political party, it will be impossible for us not to take action and to ignore it." It then asks: "The Co-operative is a financial supporter of the Co-operative party, which fields candidates in UK national, devolved and local elections in partnership with the Labour party. Were you aware of this before today?" It then asks those taking the survey whether they agree with a range of statements. One says, "The Co-operative should first use its money to lower its prices before it considers providing funding for a political party." A second says: "It is inappropriate for the Co-operative to give financial support to a political party." The only option to support the financial link is in the statement "It makes me more likely to purchase goods or services from the Co-operative."

webTitle: Dixons hits back at internet rival AO.com

fields.standfirst: Prior to AO.com's flotation, electrical giant claims its prices are lower and that its internet sales will be larger within two years
fields.body:
Electrical giant Dixons has fired a broadside at internet rival AO.com, claiming its prices are lower and that its internet sales will overtake those of its online-only competitor within two years.

AO, formerly Appliances Online, is expected to be valued at £1bn-£1.2bn when it debuts on the stock exchange in March. The hype around the flotation has knocked the Dixons share price and there are concerns that it will lose sales to its ambitious smaller rival.

At the moment AO focuses on the £3.2bn major domestic appliance market which includes everyday gadgets such as fridges and washing machines, but its growth plans include new areas, such as televisions, as well as a move overseas, resulting in a greater overlap with Dixons.

Founded by entrepreneur John Roberts, AO made a profit of £8.1m on sales of £275m last year. Given the size of the business, the heady float price tag has surprised some analysts, leading to comparisons with the hubris of the dotcom boom.

In a presentation circulated among investors, Dixons said its internet sales had been growing at 47% a year for nearly four years – faster than the 30% growth rate reported by AO – and that it was taking market share. The report also claimed Dixons' prices were 3% lower than online rivals.

Dixons had a torrid time during the financial crisis but is now on a surer footing after shedding problem businesses and a pick-up in consumer confidence. With annual sales of £8.2bn, the owner of Currys and a network of overseas chains is the far larger of the two businesses although its UK online market share in domestic appliances is roughly the same. Independent retail analyst Nick Bubb said if the same valuation logic was applied to Dixons' internet business as to AO, it would be worth £1.6bn, which is currently the market capitalisation of the whole group.

Barclays analyst Christodoulos Chaviaras said the "noise" caused by AO's intention to float and the associated negative impact on Dixons' share price had been "overdone". "Our analysis shows that Dixons and and AO's prices are similar while Dixons' service levels have been rapidly improving to a very competitive level. We do not dismiss AO as a credible competitor and Dixons shouldn't do either...but we have yet too see any evidence of AO impeding Dixons' growth." Dixons shares closed up nearly 3% at 48.4p.

webTitle: Mary Portas' Kinky Knickers to go back into production

fields.standfirst: The British factory that makes the lingerie range has been rescued from administration by its management team
fields.body:
Mary Portas' Kinky Knickers lingerie range is to go back into production after the British factory that makes the garments was rescued from administration by its management team.

Twelve of the original 33 jobs at the Headon & Quarmby factory in Middleton, Greater Manchester, are to be saved after managing director David Moore set up a new company to buy the assets of the 79-year-old business originally started by his grandparents.

Portas reopened the sewing room at the factory when she launched her lingerie range as part of the Channel 4 series Mary's Bottom Line, which was a high-profile attempt to focus on how the UK manufacturing industry could be revived.

However, Headon & Quarmby was forced to call in administrators last month after incurring bad debts.

Moore said: "We have a strong underlying business and a full order book. We're determined to rebuild a great British success story, thanks to the support of our staff, retailers, suppliers and Mary Portas."

Kerry Bailey, restructuring partner at accountancy firm BDO which handled the administration process, said the support of a large number of independent retailers had enabled the management team to successfully finance a bid for the business.

webTitle: Ryanair and easyJet fined a total €1m in Italy for mis-selling travel insurance

fields.standfirst: Competition watchdog says airlines misled customers, charged excessive fees and put obstacles in the way of making a claim
fields.body:
Ryanair and easyJet have been fined a total of more than €1m (£820,000) by the Italian competition watchdog for mis-selling travel insurance on their websites.

The Autorità Garante della Concorrenza e del Mercato (AGCM) said both airlines had infringed its consumer code by not supplying adequate information or by giving misleading information.

Ryanair, which recently committed to "stop unnecessarily pissing people off" as part of an image revamp, was fined €850,000 and given 30 days to respond on how it would change its "unfair commercial practices". EasyJet was fined a much lower €200,000 as the regulator said the airline had made the necessary changes to its booking process.

The unfair practices included a lack of transparency about the insurance policies the airlines were selling and the obstacles to making a claim.

The booking websites did not make clear the extent of the policy excess, nor that taxes and airport charges were covered, while obstacles to claimants included having to call a premium-rate phone number and pay for a certificate proving that they had not travelled, costing €20 from Ryanair or €12 from easyJet.

The regulator said this was "information which the companies already have and could be easily given to the insurance company without any burden to consumers". Instead, the fees, phone call costs and high excesses in the policy were combined deterrents to claiming.

The AGCM noted that the combined costs could be higher than the insurance policy itself, and relatively high compared with the flight fare. Data collected by the AGCM during its investigations showed that an extremely low percentage of travellers covered had tried to claim on their insurance.

The authority also took a dim view of Ryanair's "unfair, cumbersome and misleading" practice of opting customers in to buying its travel insurance as default. Those wishing not to buy insurance from the Irish airline have to select a "No Grazie" option nestling between Malta and Norway in a drop-down list of countries of residence.

EasyJet said it was disappointed that the authority had decided to fine it for the way it sold travel insurance. A spokeswoman said: "All of the issues raised in the decision have already been remedied in consultation with the AGCM and our insurance partner, Allianz. EasyJet will examine the decision and review its options."

A Ryanair spokesman said: "We note this ruling and while we disagree with its findings and have instructed our lawyers to appeal, we will be amending our website accordingly."

Selling add-ons has become an increasingly important part of Ryanair's business model, with total ancillary revenues accounting for over €1bn or around 22% of the Irish airline's overall revenues in 2013. However, easyJet reported last year that commission from selling travel insurance was continuing to decline, as the airline reported "non-seat revenues" of just £64m.

Low-cost airlines' added charges have attracted the attention of regulators in the UK too in recent years. The Office of Fair Trading investigated adverts from easyJet and others in 2012 and ordered that the headline price displayed to customers, including on first flight searches, should not exclude supplementary fees for using debit cards.

  • Matteo Renzi to form Italy’s next government
  • Inequality puts US on path to ‘Downton Abbey’ economy- Summers
  • Troika to return to Greece this week
fields.body:
5.43pm GMT

European markets dip but UK on the rise

After a strong performance in Asia overnight following positive Chinese lending figures, UK shares ended a quiet day sharply higher. But other European markets fared less well, edging slightly lower. There was no guidance from Wall Street, closed for the President’s Day holiday. The closing scores were:

• The FTSE 100 finished up 72.38 points or 1.09% at 6736.00

• Germany’s Dax dipped 0.06% to 9656.76

• France’s Cac closed 0.11% lower at 4335.17

• Italy’s FTSE MIB edged up 0.11% to 20,459.65

• Spain’s Ibex slipped 0.14% to 10,118.6

• The Athens market dipped 0.28% to 1276.81

And on that note, it’s time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we’ll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 5.43pm GMT

5.28pm GMT

In Greece, the eurogroup’s decision to put off negotiations on whether to extend a third financial package of the country and write off at least some of its debt is causing consternation. With the Troika poised to return as early as this week, Helena Smith reports:

With Greece’s political landscape becoming ever more tense ahead of euro elections in May, officials tonight are expressing consternation at the reluctance of creditor states to discuss what the country needs most: debt relief as soon as possible. One insider with close ties to the inner workings of prime minister Antonis Samaras’ two-party coalition, said: “we are constantly getting mixed messages. The feeling is, that partly as a result of tensions with [auditors representing] the troika, they are acting in bad faith.”

Putting an end to speculation that creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF would agree to some form of debt forgiveness before the European parliament poll, the Dutch finance minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem who heads the eurogroup of eurozone finance ministers, told reporters earlier today that any decision would be made “after the summer.”

While Greece’s monumental debt load – at 176 % of GDP widely accepted as the root of the country’s fiscal woes – “has to be reduced,” Dijsselbloem insisted there was no urgency as under its current €240bn bailout programme, Athens’ financing needs would be covered through the summer. The Greek finance minister, Yannis Stournaras, has repeatedly reminded the country’s creditors of their promise to extend debt relief once Athens achieved a primary surplus which he says it attained in 2013 and is on course to officially reveal in April.

In an interview with the Sunday Vima, the Greek prime minister went further estimating that Greece would post a primary surplus of €1.5bn – almost twice the €831m originally envisaged - describing it not only as being earlier than expected but “official and huge.”

Contradicting suggestions made by German Finance minister Wolfgang Schauble that plans were underway for a third bailout, Samaras has also denied that the country requires more aid. Last week he told the mass-selling Bild newpaper: “We do not need a new, third aid program. We are reaching the goals of our current program and it is showing results.”

A debt write-down would be seen as a major coup for a government that has become increasingly fragile as unemployment and poverty soars.

5.06pm GMT

And that appears to be that for the Eurogroup press conference.

5.01pm GMT

The Eurogroup moves on to Greece and Cyprus:

And Italy, in the wake of the recent political change:

And on banking union, don’t hold your breath:

Updated at 5.04pm GMT

4.48pm GMT

International inspectors are to return to Greece in the coming days, Eurogroup president Jeroen Dijsselbloen has said.

In a press conference currently underway (live stream here) following the Eurogroup meeting, he also said he was confident of getting an agreement from eurozone ministers in March on direct bank recapitalisation via the European Stability Mechanism.

Meanwhile Olli Rehn, European Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, is also speaking on Greece. He said the country’s fiscal outcome for 2013 might be better than expected, although this would have to wait for verification from Eurostat.

Updated at 4.53pm GMT

3.47pm GMT

Ratings agency Fitch said the change of power in Italy highlighted the volatility of the country’s politics:

Uncertainty about the durability of governments and their capacity for structural reform and fiscal consolidation is one reason for the Negative Outlook on Italy’s ‘BBB+’ rating.

This is the latest episode of political volatility since last February’s inconclusive parliamentary elections (increased political uncertainty, combined with the depth of Italy’s recession, prompted our downgrade to ‘BBB+’ in March). Letta’s “grand coalition”, which took office in April, has already changed shape because of the split in the centre-right that created the New Centre Right (NCD) party. Despite the coalition’s legislative majority, policies like those in the draft 2014 budget reflected political bargaining and disputes between and within the major political parties.

It is not yet clear what continuity there will be between Renzi’s administration and Letta’s. NCD leader Angelino Alfano has said that negotiations on a new government’s composition and policy programme should not be rushed. Although the PD largely backed Renzi’s challenge, it is not certain that he will receive full support on policy, especially in the upper house.

So even if there is a quicker political reconfiguration than last spring, the new prime minister will probably face similar challenges to his predecessor in building and holding together a government that can agree and enact reforms that, Fitch believes, would boost Italian economic competitiveness and growth, and comply with EU and Italian fiscal rules.

The full statement is here:

Italian PM Change Highlights Political Volatility

You may remember that Italy’s credit rating was raised to stable from negative by another agency, Moody’s, after markets closed on Friday.

Updated at 3.50pm GMT

3.21pm GMT

Francois Hollande has been busy trying to woo foreign businesses to invest in France, offering them simpler and more stable tax policies.

The French president has been hosting 30 heads of the French operations of foreign companies at the Elysee Palace and pledged that taxes on an investment would not later rise, as had happened in the past. According to Reuters:

The socialist president, who last month announced France would phase out €30bn in charges on companies by 2017 to reverse its slide in trade competitiveness, also said French business taxes would be harmonised with those of its neighbours, especially Germany, by 2020.

2.57pm GMT

The global economy will continue to grow despite choppiness in emerging markets and worries about Chinese growth.

That is the upbeat message from the Bundesbank, in its latest monthly report (German).

Germany’s central bank said China’s economy was set to continue growing without much disruption, despite interest rate rises as central banks in some emerging economies attempt to curb capital outflows and currency falls, amid jitters about the withdrawal of US stimulus.

Even if this should slow the economic growth of the countries concerned, their low global weight means it is not to be expected that the recovery of the world economy will be appreciably affected.

The bank also noted that economic growth had “increased appreciably” in the final quarter of 2013 and the first of 2014, noting “almost continual improvement” in companies’ and households’ assessment of the economy.

However, this should only fully show up in the GDP growth rates at the turn of the year, when the increased order inflow translates into production.

On that note, I am passing over to Nick Fletcher, who will run the blog for the rest of today. Thank you for all your comments so far.

2.38pm GMT

Libor update (see further 12.14):

The three ex-Barclays men charged with manipulating the Libor rate are due to appear in court on 26 February.

Two of them, Peter Charles Johnson and Jonathan James Mathew, were Libor submitters, while Stylianos Contouglas was a trader.

2.32pm GMT

Sad news: WH Smith has scrapped many of its honesty boxes because of customer “misuse”, various newspapers report

Installed in some of WH Smith’s busiest locations, such as stations and airports, the boxes were intended to help time-poor commuters avoid the queues to buy a newspaper.

Now the retailer has been forced to abandon the scheme in a third of branches running the scheme, having found that people are filling the boxes with rubbish, foreign coins and bits of chewing gum.

One expert thinks some of the problems could have been avoided if the retailer had included a picture of eyes near the boxes. Dr Melissa Bateson studied shoppers’ behaviour when a poster of a pair of eyes was placed above an honesty box.

We got nearly three times as much money. Eyes give people the feeling they are being watched.

2.02pm GMT

France and Germany will try to revive the European transactions tax, or Robin Hood tax, according to Reuters.

The two countries, the power players of the European Union, will hold a joint cabinet meeting on Wednesday, where the plan is likely to be discussed.

Soundings will also be taken on the sidelines of the regular monthly meeting of the EU finance ministers in Brussels this afternoon.

Speaking as he arrived in Brussels for the talks, Wolfgang Schäuble, Germany’s finance minister, said:

I hope that we take a step forward on that.

We may possibly have to move ahead step by step.

European proposals for a transactions tax - a 0.1% levy on trading in bonds and equities that would throw grit into wheels of international finance - have been kicking around since the start of the financial crisis, but agreement remains distant. A group of 11 countries - including France, Germany, Italy and Spain, but not the UK - have signed up for the tax, but been unable to agree how to implement it.

Now Socialist MEPS are mobilising to support the plan. In a letter to eurozone finance ministers, they write:

We count on you to reject the special pleading of vested interests and to do what is right for our citizens and the sustainability of a robust financial sector.

1.51pm GMT

Apologies for the error messages you may be finding when you click on links on the blog. We are trying to fix this problem.

Update: the problem is fixed, but please bear with us while all the bad ones are replaced.

Updated at 2.10pm GMT

1.34pm GMT

A few more details on Ewald Nowotny’s speech that has been causing a stir.

On the ECB’s bond-buying programme, known as Outright Monetary Transactions, he said it was less significant than it was:

[The programme] not that relevant anymore because we have a substantial improvement in the European situation and there are no expectations in the market of a break-up in the euro zone.

On interest rates, he said the bank needed more information about inflation and growth before taking a decision. Rates were left on hold earlier this month.

There might be good arguments to say let’s wait and see.

On the eurozone recovery, the eurozone still faces downside risks, mainly from turmoil in financial markets, disinflation and the slow pace of implementation of structural reforms.

It’s good news that we see improvements in the real economy and how this connects to inflation rates is something that still needs to be discussed.

Updated at 1.35pm GMT

12.28pm GMT

So the euro-crisis is over? That appears to be the message from the European Central Bank governing council member Ewald Nowotny, who has said the ECB’s bond buying programme is “not that relevant” any more because of the improved economic situation.

This comes 18 months after ECB president Mario Draghi made that big promise to do “whatever it takes” to save the euro. Job done?

I’ll try and track down more details from Nowotny’s speech, but meantime, here are details, comment from Twitter.

Three ex-employees of Barclays charged over Libor fraud

The Serious Fraud Office has started criminal proceedings against three former employees of Barclays Bank for alleged manipulation of Libor interest rates.

11.55am GMT

Our friends at Fast FT report that the European Investment Bank, the EU bank, will invest £1bn a year in housing in the UK to help tackle the affordability crisis.

The paper reports that the EIB aims to provide £1bn a year in cheap loans to fund affordable housing, as part of its mandate to improve economic and social cohesion.

11.27am GMT

Renzi: next steps

We know that Renzi met Italian president Giorgio Napolitano for 90 minutes.

In the next few days, the centre-left leader will need to agree a formal coalition deal with the small centre-right NCD party to secure a governing majority and name his cabinet before seeking a formal vote of confidence in parliament later this week.

Larry Summers, the former US Treasury secretary and adviser to Barack Obama, has said inequality is putting the US on its way to becoming a Downton Abbey economy.

Here is a flavour of his argument - made in an opinion piece in the Washington Post and Financial Times (£).

The share of income going to the top 1 per cent of earners has increased sharply. A rising share of output is going to profits. Real wages are stagnant. Family incomes have not risen as fast as productivity. The cumulative effect of all these developments is that the US may well be on the way to becoming a Downton Abbey economy. It is very likely that these issues will be with us long after the cyclical conditions have normalised and budget deficits have at last been addressed.

President Barack Obama is right to be concerned. Those who condemn him for “tearing down the wealthy” and engaging in un-American populism are, to put it politely, lacking in historical perspective. Presidents from Franklin Roosevelt to Harry Truman railed against the excesses of a privileged few in finance and business... All were reacting in their own way to a phenomenon that Bill Clinton has described best: “Although America’s rich got richer ... the country did not ... the stock market tripled but wages went down.”

He also points out that “those who profess the most enthusiasm for market forces” happen to be least enthusiastic about curbing tax benefits for the wealthy.

There is a fair amount of reaction to the disappointing growth data from Japan. Most economists are expecting the economy to pick up in early 2014, but drop back following the introduction of a sales tax in April.


Takumi Tsunoda at Shinkin Central Bank Research Institute, Tokyo

Growth will almost certainly accelerate in January-March because of last-minute buying ahead of the tax hike so the question is what happens in the following quarters and that’s where opinions among investors are divided.

We think consumption will be hurt after April. Yoshiki Shinke, chief economist at Dai-Ichi Life Research Institute Tokyo

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

And it is a disappointing start to the week in Japan, with data showing its economy grew well below expectations at the end of last year.

Official figures show the economy expanded by 0.3% in October-December 2013, significantly down on the 0.7% that economists had hoped for.

Weak export growth is being blamed, but private consumption and business investment were also worse than expected, raising questions about the limits of Abenomics - prime minister Shinzo Abe’s unprecedented stimulus plan.

Those who like the glass half full, would point out this was the fourth successive quarter of growth for the Japanese economy, its best run in more than three years.

The bad news from Japan could subdue European markets in early trading.

Also worth watching is a European Central Bank meeting, where eurozone bank supervisors will gather in Frankfurt to discuss the next phase of stress tests.

I’ll be following that and all the latest economic and business news...

webTitle: FTSE hits new three week high while Essar jumps on controversial bid

fields.standfirst: Indian business receives approach from majority shareholder but move angers investors
fields.body:
A controversial takeover plan has sent a charge through shares of Essar Energy but shocked some of its shareholders.

The power plant and oil refining company, controlled by India's billionaire Ruia brothers, jumped 2.15p or more than 3% to 68.15p after they said they were considering a 70p a share offer for the remaining 22% of the company. They are also offering 80 cents for the company's convertible bonds. But not all shareholders were happy with the £900m proposal, given that Essar floated in 2010 at 420p a share. Standard Life Investments fumed that the bid, from the Ruia's Essar Global Fund, was a piece of "cynical opportunism." In a statement head of equities David Cumming said:

Essar Global's potential attempt to buy out the minority shareholder position in Essar Energy, capitalising on a technically depressed share price, is a calculated attempt to deprive minority shareholders of the substantial future upside in Essar Energy's valuation.
This potential bid is an example of cynical opportunism and should not be allowed to proceed.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 72.38 points higher at 6736.00, a new three and a half week high. The market took its lead from Asia, where shares moved higher despite disappointing Japanese growth data and following positive Chinese bank lending figures. But with half term in the UK and the US closed for the President's Day public holiday, it was a fairly subdued session.

The continuing bounce in the gold price lifted Randgold Resources 83p to £48.57 and Polymetal International 26.5p to 684p.

Other miners were supported by the Chinese data, with Anglo American adding 32.5p to £15.52 and BHP Billiton 23.5p better at £19.12.

Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, said:

Chinese bank lending data for January rose to its highest level since 2010, raising expectations that the Chinese economy could start to show signs of a rebound now that we've moved beyond Chinese New Year.

RSA Insurance rose 2.35p to 98.2p on hopes a disposal programme and cash call will put it back on track under new chief executive Stephen Hester.

Analysts believe it could announce a rights issue of up to £350m when it updates the City on 27 February. The insurer is also reported to be considering a number of disposals, the latest suggestion being a £200m sale of a network of regional brokers in Canada.

Hester, the former boss of Royal Bank of Scotland, was brought in to rebuild the business after an accounting scandal in Ireland.

But the continuing extreme weather is likely to cost the company a substantial amount, which will hardly help the turnaround.

Housebuilding shares benefited from more evidence of rising prices, with Persimmon putting on 30p to £14.15 and Barratt Developments climbing 8.5p to 417.3p.

Hammerson - now a purely retail property developer after completing the disposal of its office properties - was 17p higher at 560.5p - the biggest riser in the FTSE 100 after it said full year net asset value rose 5.7% to 573p and profits climbed from £142m to £341m. Capita has now won two of the three material bids it flagged at the third quarter (Congestion Charge and SWAN). The outcome of the larger DIO (defence infrastructure) contract is still not known/decided, although Serco are still allegedly favourite. No change to our forecasts or sell rating.

Oriel however was more positive, with a buy rating:

These wins support the group's recent run of materially ahead of a one in two win rate. We value the group at 1170p a share, assuming mid-term organic growth of 6% a year and £200m of expenditure on acquisitive growth for the next several years.

AO is expected to have a valuation of some £1bn when it joins the stock market, and news of its plans have put pressure on Dixons. But over the weekend Dixons hit back with a presentation addressing concerns about its market share and competitive position.

webTitle: Sterling's rise will have a limited run | Larry Elliott

fields.standfirst: Before long, investors will realise that UK growth has been a matter of quantity, not quality
fields.body:
Thinking about buying US dollars for your holiday in the States this year? If so, the temptation to buy now was there on Monday when the pound hit a three year high against the greenback and closed in on the $1.70 level.

Sterling slipped back later as investors took profits from the big gains seen over the past week. But it was probably just a pause for breath. There is more juice in the pound yet, but buyers beware: the rally is time-limited.

The pound has been strengthening against the dollar because the latest US economic news has been a bit iffy. While the cold weather played a part, the markets have been a tad disappointed by the jobs, consumer spending and industrial production data. Much more of it and Wall Street will start speculating about the possibility of the Federal Reserve pausing in its tapering programme – the gradual reduction in the amount of bonds bought monthly by the US central bank.

But sterling's recent rise against the dollar is part of a longer term trend in which it has risen against all major currencies over the past year. It is not hard to see why. The pound was sold off in 2012 when the economy surprised on the downside. For the past 12 months, the news from the UK has been better than expected and sterling has strengthened as a result.

What's more, despite Mark Carney's forward guidance, the financial markets have advanced the date at which they think the Bank of England will announce an interest rate rise to February next year, before they expect a move from the Fed, the ECB or the Bank of Japan.

So why should holidaymakers strike while the iron is hot? Two reasons. Recent UK growth has been a matter of quantity at the expense of quality: national output is rising because the housing market is humming and consumers are running down their savings. And a rising pound is not at all helpful when you are running a current account deficit of 5.5% of GDP. Investors will take note of that before long.

webTitle: Dixons Retail rises 3% as it tries to soothe AO competition concerns

fields.standfirst: Retailer releases report to counter worries about soon-to-be-floated rival AO
fields.body:
Dixons Retail has risen around 3% after acting to ease concerns about the competitive threat of soon to be floated Appliances Online.

AO is expected to have a valuation of some £1bn when it joins the stock market, and news of its plans have put pressure on Dixons. But over the weekend Dixons hit back with a presentation addressing concerns about its market share and competitive position.

The news has lifted Dixons shares 1.43p higher to 48.52p, and prompted a buy note from Barclays. Analysts Christodoulos Chaviaras and Claire Huff put a 65p target on Dixons, and said that investors had probably overestimated the threat that AO posed to its business. They said:

Dixons' presentation addresses a number of investors' concerns about the company's market share and marketing position versus AO.com which has attracted a lot of interest recently. Clearly we cannot fully endorse the estimates coming from either Dixons' or OC&C's (commissioned by AO) reports as we cannot verify the data ourselves but in our view the noise caused by AO's intention to float and the associated negative impact on Dixons' share price is overdone.
Our analysis shows that Dixons' and AO's prices are similar while Dixons' service levels have been rapidly improving to a very competitive level. In our estimates Dixons gained circa one-third of Comet's lost sales meaning that it has been able to accelerate its market share gains in the white goods market and certainly didn't lose market share due to AO's sales growth. Some sensible checks we did on the facts presented by both Dixons and AO lead to an overall picture which is not very dissimilar to how the two retailers presented it. We do not dismiss AO as a credible competitor in the major domestic appliances [MDA] market and Dixons shouldn't do either, in our view, but we have yet to see any evidence of AO impeding Dixons' growth. The five main points Dixons management highlights in its presentation 1. Dixons is the market leader in UK and Ireland MDA while its market share online is very close to AO's market share. 2. Dixons' MDA online sales have been growing at a faster pace than AO's in the last 3.75 years hence Dixons has actually gained more market share than AO contrary to the bears' beliefs that they have been losing share. 3. Dixons is cheaper than AO in terms of prices and services provided. 4. The strong feedback from Dixons' customers is not very dissimilar to AO's although the two have chosen different sources to draw customer feedback from. 5. Dixons' brand awareness is much higher than AO's and hence customer acquisition costs are lower. In general Dixons claims that its multichannel model is more profitable than a pure online model.

webTitle: Farmfoods shocks industry by becoming fastest-growing grocer

fields.standfirst: Frozen food retailer experiences growth 'similar to Aldi and Lidl' in same 12 weeks Morrisons and Tesco saw sales fall
fields.body:
In a food retail market that currently favours the discount Davids over the grocery Goliaths, one particular upstart has put in a storming performance over the past six months.

Family-owned Farmfoods, the tiny frozen food retailer based in Cumbernauld, Scotland, has astonished industry watchers as it has gone from shrinking sales to become the fastest-growing grocer.

The latest research from market analysts Kantar Worldpanel suggests Farmfoods sales were nearly 44% higher in the 12 weeks to 2 February compared with the same period last year.

A retail analyst at Kantar, Fraser McKevitt, said the figures should be taken with a pinch of salt because the small scale of Farmfoods makes it more difficult to track its sales patterns. But he said: "I think growth is in strong double digits, similar to Aldi and Lidl [which stand at 32% and 17% respectively]."

In the same 12 weeks, Morrisons and Tesco saw sales fall, according to Kantar Worldpanel. Asda's sales rose just 0.5% – below the 2.4% growth achieved by the market as a whole.

It is not just in groceries where shoppers' pursuit of a bargain has favoured price-cutters recently. Poundland is expected to confirm plans to float on the London stock market this week. The low-price retailer chaired by Tesco's former finance director Andy Higginson is expected to seek a total valuation of about £750m. B&M, a discount retailer set up in Blackpool with just £750 in 1978, is also preparing for a stock market flotation that could value it at £2bn.

Beginning as a humble meat processor in 1955, Farmfoods opened its first experimental shop in Aberdeen in the early 1970s. It did not step outside its Scottish birthplace until the 1990s, but has gradually crept as far south as Plymouth in Devon. Today it has more than 320 stores and recent adverts have been fronted by Strictly Come Dancing judge Len Goodman.

Pre-tax profits for 2012 were up 10% to £27m and the company handed out a £10.2m dividend to its shareholders – nearly all members of the founding Herd family. That payout was up from £6.8m a year before, according to accounts filed at Companies House.

The major shareholder is also the boss and son of the founder. Eric Herd may be enjoying the fruits of his business, having collected about £8m of the last reported dividend, but he remains media shy. The bespectacled, golf-loving Scotsman sticks to touring his stores and getting involved in the detail of the business, politely turning away interview requests.

The director-general of the British Frozen Food Federation, Brian Young, describes Herd as a "canny Scotsman". He said: "He really understands frozen food. He could give you a story about each of his products."

It is his eye-catching deals, such as four litres of milk for £1.60 and 30 frozen pork steaks for £10, that are drawing in shoppers rather than rapidly opening stores.

An analyst at Verdict Research, Andy Stevens, said: "It's about more people shopping there. They may not get the greatest product quality, but [Farmfoods] is appealing to the sort of customer who is really value-driven."

All the frozen food retailers have been enjoying strong growth throughout the UK's economic downturn. Apart from the inherently lower cost of frozen food, which is cheaper to transport and store than fresh, Farmfoods keeps prices low by offering own-label alternatives such as Betty Smith's.

Meanwhile, shelves above the freezers are piled high with tempting deals on biscuits, soft drinks and household essentials such as toilet roll. With many of those items displayed on small pallets or in boxes, it feels almost like a small-scale Lidl.

As shoppers' budgets remain under pressure, Verdict predicts Farmfoods will see sales rise by 9% in the year ahead, well beyond the 2% expected for the grocery market as a whole. Stevens said the majority of that growth was coming from underlying sales growth, not new stores.

He may not be big on ego, but Herd is clearly ambitious. In 2011, he teamed up with Asda, the Walmart-owned British supermarket, as part of a plan to buy out Iceland, Farmfoods' bigger rival. That plan could have resulted in Farmfoods adding as many as 200 new stores unwanted by Asda.

With some good sales momentum behind him this year, Herd may be looking for other ways to scale up the business as he battles for appropriate sites with the likes of Aldi, Lidl and Iceland. The company lists hundreds of locations Farmfoods as targets on its website.

So far progress has been slow and steady. Although Farmfoods has been established longer than Iceland, today it is less than a quarter the size of its bigger rival.

The family has also shown little sign of enthusiasm for bringing in outside investment to step up the pace and buy out smaller rivals such as Frozen Value, which trades as Fultons Foods.

Herd owns the majority of the business after buying out his brother Gordon's 21.2% stake in 2004, for £10.3m. Meanwhile deputy chairman and property expert William McCreadie, the only non-family shareholder, retired last year, selling his stake to the family and lifting Herd's personal shareholding slightly to 83%.

That gives Herd the flexibility to run the business for growth or profits as he sees fit, but may limit his firepower if the market gets tougher.

Analysts say frozen foods specialists are likely to see growth slow if shoppers begin to feel better off this year, and devote less energy to shopping around for the best deals.

A retail analyst at Planet Retail, David Gray, said: "Frozen food stores saw rapid growth during the recession, there was a bit of a boom. But now the supermarkets have cottoned on and tightened up their act." Gray is not expecting Farmfoods to show much sales growth at all in the next few years after a tough 2012.

That year, the most recent for which published figures are available, Farmfoods may have seen profits rise as it trimmed costs, but sales slipped back 1.5% from 2011.

Industry insiders suggest that more recently Farmfoods has gained momentum by undercutting bigger rival Iceland on price on certain key items in an attempt to steal away shoppers. But such a move, if true, is likely to be unsustainable, said Gray.

Meanwhile, greater scale might also bring tougher scrutiny of the quality of Farmfoods' products.

Right now, all the attention is on Farmfoods' strength in a weak market. But this stripling will have to pull off some moves niftier than one of Goodman's dancing trainees to avoid being stomped on by bigger rivals who need all the sales they can find.

webTitle: Exports to blame for Japan's weak growth | Phillip Inman

fields.bodyText: Blame for Japan's disappointingly weak growth in the last three months of 2013 can be laid at the door of exporters. webTitle: Former Barclays bankers charged over Libor allegations

fields.standfirst: The three men are the first former or existing Barclays staff named in criminal proceedings linked to interest rate fixing allegations
fields.body:
Three former Barclays bankers have been charged in relation to allegations of a conspiracy to manipulate Libor interest rates.

The Serious Fraud Office said the men were charged in connection with an allegation of conspiracy to defraud between 1 June 2005 and 31 August 2007.

The bank was fined £290m by US and UK regulators two years ago for a "serious, widespread" role in trying to manipulate Libor rates. There was no admission of criminal liability but the scandal ultimately led to the departure of the chief executive, Bob Diamond.

Although Barclays was the first of several banks to reach a regulatory settlement of Libor allegations, neither existing nor former employees had been named in criminal proceedings until Monday.

The focus of criminal proceedings until now has been a former Citigroup and UBS trader, Tom Hayes, who is charged with conspiracy to fix Libor with employees at eight other financial firms including Royal Bank of Scotland, JP Morgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, Icap, Tullett Prebon, Rabobank RP Martin and HSBC.

It is thought that the latest charges brought against former Barclays staff relate to a separate alleged conspiracy, unrelated to the alleged plots between August 2006 and September 2010 involving Hayes.

The three former Barclays bankers are Jonathan Mathew, who worked in the bank's treasury unit in London and left this position in September 2012, Peter Johnson, who is thought to have been a senior dollar Libor submitter in London, and Stylianos Contogoulas, a former trader at Barclays who moved to Merrill Lynch in July 2006 and left there in September 2011.

Barclays declined to comment.

webTitle: Co-op polls public on its future

fields.standfirst: After banking scandal, group sounds out public on the dividends and whether it should continue to make political donations
fields.body:
The Co-operative Group has launched a wide-ranging poll about its future, including whether it should keep making political donations of up to £1m.

In what is thought to be the first survey of its kind, the group is also asking the public for its views on the dividend paid to its members and on what it can do to help local communities following a series of scandals inside its banking arm.

The bank's failed bid to buy 631 branches from Lloyds Banking Group caused a political furore, and led to allegations that Paul Flowers, the former chairman of the bank and a member of the main group board, had been involved in buying illegal drugs.

The Co-op was instructed by the Bank of England to raise £1.5bn last year, which forced the 170-year-old group to cede 70% ownership of the bank to a group of bondholders led by US hedge funds.

The organisation, which also owns supermarkets, pharmacies, funeral homes and farms, is launching the survey with an advertising campaign. The most controversial of the questions may prove to be the one about political donations, given the group's links to the Co-operative party, which has 32 MPs in parliament, including the shadow chancellor, Ed Balls.

But the survey swiftly prompted criticism. Andre Spicer, professor of organisational behaviour at Cass Business School, said: "It runs the risk of being seen as just another customer survey that mainstream companies do every day and we are all fed up with.

"The survey runs the risk of being seen as another sign of how distanced the senior management of the Co-op group is from its member base. If it is interested in rebuilding participation, the Co-op group needs to address the growing gap between senior management and the membership base.

"A frequent complaint among Co-op members is that the group is too large, too centralised and too dominated by a cadre of professional managers."

Euan Sutherland, chief executive of the Co-op group since May, when the problems at the bank were uncovered, wants the survey to help restore the organisation's standing as the UK's biggest mutual. "In recent years, the Co-operative has lost touch with its customers and members and with the communities in which it operates," he warned. "We haven't been listening. As a new management team, we are focusing on reviewing the Co-operative, and the UK public will be vital to that process."

Describing the survey as unprecedented, he added: "If we are to successfully serve the communities in which we operate, to become as relevant today as we were in the past, we need to hear directly from the communities and the people we serve. We have seen incredible loyalty from our customers, colleagues and members in recent months – and we want to reward loyalty."

The group, which traces its roots to the Rochdale pioneers in 1844, has permission to hand out £1m in annual donations, and gave just over £500,000 to the Co-op party in 2012. As a result of the problems in the bank, the group reported a £599m loss in August, and just before Christmas suspended its dividend to members.

The survey will ask how profits – once they are generated again – should be shared. The group said the results would be announced at the annual general meeting in May, and published online. The survey closes on 24 March and forms part of a strategy review launched by Sutherland.

It is separate from a review of corporate governance by the former City minister Lord Myners, and another that is being promised by the new management of the Co-op Bank, which pledges to keep its ethical stance even though the mutual now owns just 30% of the business.

webTitle: Hammerson builds up 4% rise after positive results

fields.standfirst: Retail specialist sees its shopping centres benefit from recovery in UK economy
fields.body:
Hammerson - now a purely retail property developer after completing the disposal of its office properties - is benefiting from the recent revival in the UK economy.

The company, whose shopping centres include the Bull Ring in Birmingham and Les Terrasses du Port in Marseille, said full year net asset value rose 5.7% to 573p and profits climbed from £142m to £341m. Its Value Retail business, which operates luxury outlet villages in the UK and Europe including Bicester in Oxfordshire and La Vallee near Paris, saw double digit sales growth.

Importantly, overall occupancy increased to 97.7% since the half year.

Chief executive David Atkins said:

We have reported a good set of results in a year when we saw the beginning of economic and consumer recovery in the UK. In France the economic picture is less clear cut, although personal debt levels remain low, providing the opportunity for a rebound in consumer spending when growth returns.
We remain on course to deliver strong growth in earnings and dividends over the medium term.

The news has lifted Hammerson shares by 23p or 4% to 566.5p, making them the biggest riser in the FTSE 100 at the moment. Analysts at Liberum issued a buy note with a 617p price target, saying:

We continue to see Hammerson as the best play on a UK economic recovery amongst our retail real estate investment trust coverage.

Oriel Securities was also positive:

The results are in line with expectations, surprising slightly with higher earnings, as Hammerson continues to perform well operationally. Though retail as an asset class faces headwinds from changing consumer behaviour (internet retail, click and collect etc), the company has a substantial development programme, and its equity exposure to Value Retail gives rise to strongly growing earnings. As such, Hammerson is our preferred retail company of the large caps.

But Peel Hunt kept a hold recommendation with a 550p target price:

The result is ahead of our expectations and demonstrates the company's ability to perform in a tough market. Footfall and retail sales fell in the UK and France, yet management maintained occupancy and increased rent. Value retail and developments are likely to continue to boost the valuation, and today we increase our target price but retain our large-cap preference for British Land, because of the latter's City/West End exposure plus larger dividend.

webTitle: RSA Insurance rises on hopes of disposals and £350m cash call

fields.standfirst: Leading shares move higher in quiet trading despite weak Japanese figures
fields.body:
RSA Insurance has jumped to the top of the FTSE 100 on hopes a disposal programme and cash call will put it back on track under new chief executive Stephen Hester.

Analysts believe it could announce a rights issue of up to £350m when it updates the City on 27 February. The insurer is also reported to be considering a number of disposals, the latest suggestion being a £200m sale of a network of regional brokers in Canada.

Hester, the former boss of Royal Bank of Scotland, was brought in to rebuild the business after an accounting scandal in Ireland.

But the continuing extreme weather is likely to cost the company a substantial amount, which will hardly help the turnaround.

Nevertheless, its shares have climbed 2.5p to 98.35p ahead of its strategic update. Canaccord Genuity has raised its rating to hold but Andy Hughes at Exane BNP Paribas was more cautious. He said:

We see a compelling cash flow story in 2016. Nevertheless, we believe the stock will continue to perform poorly ahead of an expected capital increase, which we now incorporate into our forecasts. We have accordingly taken the painful decision to downgrade to neutral. We think the strategic review is being driven by the demands of the rating agencies for an A range rating. Recent events in terms of continuing adverse weather and Ireland reserving have exposed weaknesses in RSA's balance sheet, where we believe the capital has always been weaker than suggested by its credit rating. The amount of debt qualifying as capital for rating agencies will also have been compressed.
Given the continuing bad weather in the UK, we expect the group to announce a rights issue of £350m and pay the full year dividend as scrip. This should be enough to preserve the rating, especially when combined with a refocus on cash flow. Once the capital increase and disposals have been completed, the cash flow projections out to 2016 should look very positive; we think £400m-£600m in 2016 could be set as a target. This could see cash dividends reinstated at a higher rate, as the benefits of restructuring and cost cutting flow through. [We expect] disposal proceeds/capital release of £400m in addition to the rights issue. We expect several non-cash generating businesses to be given non-core status, with the proceeds used to call the expensive sub debt due in December 2014.

Overall, the UK market has taken its lead from Asia, where shares moved higher despite disappointing Japanese growth data. Analysts said the figures suggested further economic stimulus measures were likely.

So the FTSE 100 is currently 43.41 points higher at 6707.03. But with half term and the US closed for a public holiday, traders expect a fairly subdued session.

The continuing bounce in the gold price has lifted Randgold Resources 99p to £48.73 and Polymetal International 24.5p to 682p.

Housebuilding shares benefited from more evidence of rising prices, with Persimmon putting on 24p to £14.09 and Taylor Wimpey edging 0.4p higher at 121.7p.

webTitle: Unemployment rate same as 10 years ago, but what lies ahead is a worry

fields.standfirst: Australia’s economic vantage point in 2003 painted a much rosier picture than now
fields.body:
Last week came the news that for the first time in more than a decade Australia’s unemployment rate was at 6%. The last time Australia’s unemployment rate had a six in front of it was back in July 2003. But other than that number, very little is the same between now and then. In 2003, the future was looking bright; now the picture is decidedly gloomy.

What is clear when looking at the past is that in July 2003 the trajectory of the unemployment rate was going down. This in itself is not stunning – if it was not the case then it would not have been the last time the unemployment rate was that high.

The first thing whenever looking at the unemployment rate is of course to acknowledge that by itself it is a pretty bland number.

If you look at the growth in annual employment and the labour force (the employed and unemployed), both including those in work, the difference in situations is quite stark.

In July 2003, employment was growing at 2.1% per annum, compared with the mere 0.3% from January 2013 to January 2014. Also, despite the high unemployment rate, the period prior to July 2003 had seen employment grow by more than the overall labour force in 16 out of the previous 21 months. However, January 2014 marked the 14th consecutive month where employment grew less than did size of the labour force in trend terms. For more than a year not enough jobs have been created to cover the new entrants into the labour force.

Mostly this lack of new jobs can be put down to the weak growth in the economy. This is also another difference between now and 2003. Midway through 2003 Australia’s economy had been growing above trend of 3% for four of the previous five years; whereas now Australia has been growing below trend for four of the previous five.

And while at June 2003, the economy had grown by only 3.1% in real terms (adjusted for inflation) – Australia was about to embark on the mining boom, shown by the phenomenal nominal gross domestic product (GDP) growth during that period. From 1999-2000 to 2008-09 nominal GDP grew by more than 6% each year. This growth flowed through into the government’s coffers. By contrast the nominal GDP growth in 2012-13 was just 2.5%.

Similarly our current inflation and wages growth is below where it was in 2003. Back then the growth in employment – not the level of unemployment – was fuelling a growth in wages, whereas in June last year wages grew by a mere 2.9%, and have fallen even further since then.

The changed economic picture is also evident in the level of interest rates. In 2003 the rate was at 4.75% and on the way up as the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) tried to stifle inflationary pressures coming from the mining boom by encouraging people to save, not spend. Now we find ourselves with rates at 2.5% and the RBA having spent two years trying to induce some life into the economy by encouraging spending and investment.

Perhaps the biggest difference between 2003 and 2013 is the growth in the terms of trade. The terms of trade measures the price of our exports and imports. When it rises it means the price we get for our exports is rising faster than the price we pay for our imports. In 2003 the terms of trade grew by only 1.5%, but the next five years would see it grow by more than 5% each year as the price of iron ore and other minerals soared. In 2012-13 however the terms of trade fell by 9.8%. That fall led to a fall in mining investment, and thus a fall in jobs in mining. The drop in investment in that sector flows through to the rest of the economy and thus other industries also see a drop in both investment and then jobs.

The increase in Australia’s export prices from 2003, which led to the growth in the overall economy and in the labour market, was fuelled by China. China’s economy in 2003 grew by 10% and would grow faster than that for the next four years. For Australia to now experience a similar improvement as occurred in 2003, we need China’s economy to begin growing faster than its current rate of 7.6%.

Unfortunately no one thinks that is likely.

And that’s bad news for the current unemployed who over the past few years have been finding themselves unemployed for longer periods. In 2003 the proportion of the unemployed who had been looking for work for less than three months was increasing. This is a good sign because the better the chances of getting a job, the more likely you will be unemployed for a short period.

In the past few years however, the proportion of those unemployed for less than three months has fallen from 48% to now about 43%. In the same period the level of long-term unemployed (those unemployed for more than a year) has risen.

While there was a greater proportion of long-term unemployed in 2003, it was falling fast:

The recently released annual job search experience survey from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) also gives us an indicator of the changes in difficulties for the unemployed in 2003 compared with now.

In 2003 the most common difficulty for those seeking work was being considered too young or old (mostly too old). Now that is only the seventh most stated difficulty.

Overwhelmingly the most common difficulty for the unemployed now is competition for job vacancies. And the inability to get work does not seem to be due to lack of skills or experience. Both of these reasons were more common in 2003, indicating that the labour market at the time, despite the same unemployment rate, was actually easier. When the percentage of the unemployed who have the skills and experience necessary to get a particular job is increasing, it is a clear sign that it is getting tougher to get work.

Overall, the unemployment rate in 2003 is the same as now, but looking at the bigger picture we see very much opposite pictures. One picture looks quite optimistic; one suggests a tough period ahead. For the unemployed now, unfortunately it is their picture that is the bleaker one.

In 2003 the terms of trade grew by only 1.5%, but the next five years would see it grow by more than 5% each year as the price of iron ore and other minerals soared. In 2012-13 however the terms of trade fell by 9.8%. That fall led to a fall in mining investment, and thus a fall in jobs in mining. The drop in investment in that sector flows through to the rest of the economy and thus other industries also see a drop in both investment and then jobs. The increase in Australia’s export prices from 2003, which led to the growth in the overall economy and in the labour market, was fuelled by China. China’s economy in 2003 grew by 10% and would grow faster than that for the next four years. For Australia to now experience a similar improvement as occurred in 2003, we need China’s economy to begin growing faster than its current rate of 7.6%. Unfortunately no one thinks that is likely. And that’s bad news for the current unemployed who over the past few years have been finding themselves unemployed for longer periods. In 2003 the proportion of the unemployed who had been looking for work for less than three months was increasing. This is a good sign because the better the chances of getting a job, the more likely you will be unemployed for a short period. In the past few years however, the proportion of those unemployed for less than three months has fallen from 48% to now about 43%. In the same period the level of long-term unemployed (those unemployed for more than a year) has risen. While there was a greater proportion of long-term unemployed in 2003, it was falling fast: The recently released annual job search experience survey from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) also gives us an indicator of the changes in difficulties for the unemployed in 2003 compared with now. In 2003 the most common difficulty for those seeking work was being considered too young or old (mostly too old). Now that is only the seventh most stated difficulty. Overwhelmingly the most common difficulty for the unemployed now is competition for job vacancies. And the inability to get work does not seem to be due to lack of skills or experience. Both of these reasons were more common in 2003, indicating that the labour market at the time, despite the same unemployment rate, was actually easier. When the percentage of the unemployed who have the skills and experience necessary to get a particular job is increasing, it is a clear sign that it is getting tougher to get work. Overall, the unemployment rate in 2003 is the same as now, but looking at the bigger picture we see very much opposite pictures. One picture looks quite optimistic; one suggests a tough period ahead. For the unemployed now, unfortunately it is their picture that is the bleaker one.
fields.headline: Unemployment rate same as 10 years ago, but what lies ahead is a worry
fields.trailText: Australia’s economic vantage point in 2003 painted a much rosier picture than now
